Situation1: They are asked to take part in an important family event like a holiday celebration or trip.
Expectation2: Meet sales targets set by management
Situation2: Midway through the week, their individual sales numbers are already on pace to surpass the quota.
Story: I stared at my phone, the sales dashboard glowing with numbers that made my heart race. I was so close to smashing my weekly target, and it was only Wednesday. Every call I made felt like a step closer to the recognition I’d been craving at work. But then my sister’s message popped up: “Don’t forget, we’re leaving for the family trip tomorrow. Mom’s counting on you to help with the kids.” I could almost hear my mother’s voice, warm but firm, reminding me how important it was to be present, to make memories together. My mind spun with the pressure—my manager’s praise if I kept dialing, my family’s disappointment if I didn’t show up. I wanted to be the reliable sister, the one who never missed a holiday, but I also wanted to prove myself at work, to finally be seen as more than just another voice on the phone. The weight of both expectations pressed down on me, and I sat frozen, torn between the ringing phone and the family waiting for me.
